10904Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-008-9208-x920810.1007/s10904-008-9208-xArticleCobalt(ethylenediamine)sulfate: A Pillared Layered Coordination PolymerLauchanSanchai1PriorTimothy J.2MeansiriSanti3RujiwatraApinpus4dgrid.7132.70000000090397662Department of Physics, Faculty of ScienceChiang Mai University50200Chiang MaiThailand, ROCgrid.9481.40000000404128669Department of ChemistryUniversity of HullHU6 7RXKingston upon HullUKgrid.9786.00000000404700856Department of Physics, Faculty of ScienceKhon Kaen University40002Khon KaenThailand, ROCgrid.7132.70000000090397662Inorganic Materials Research Unit, Department of Chemistry, Faculty of ScienceChiang Mai University50200Chiang MaiThailand, ROC+66-53-941906+66-53-892277apinpus@chiangmai.ac.th235200892008183352357135200881200830420082352008© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20082008Abstract

A pillared-layered coordination polymer of formula Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition, and fully characterized. The three-dimensional structure of 1 is built up from cobalt sulfate sheets, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra, with ethylenediamine pillars connecting the adjacent sheets. The coordinate covalent and hydrogen bonds have been revealed to exhibit an important role in the organization of the structure. The compound is found to be thermally stable up to, and above, 573 K and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature.

The best known of the three-dimensional open framework solids are the zeolites, which are composed solely of SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedral building units. These materials have found applications in a variety of fields such as catalysis, selective sorption, and ion exchange [1, 2]. Interest in these materials has been focused on the synthesis of similar extended networks with other tetrahedral units such as phosphate [3]. Another class of three-dimensional framework solids contemporarily capturing wide interest is of the pillared-layered structures [3]. In both classes of framework solids, the introduction of a transition metal into the framework has also been a key goal in recent years. Metal sulfate networks, in particular with cobalt sulfate, have been scarcely reported, although the sulfate group provides good thermal stability and the cobalt offers promising redox and magnetic properties [4, 5]. Moreover, the function of the sulfate in the reported structures is mostly limited to either a charge balancing guest or a terminal pendant unit [4–9]. There are, however, a few examples in which the sulfate acts as a bridge to establish the desired networks [10, 11]. In addition, most of these structures are of low (one or two) dimension.

Our work has focused on the search for new three-dimensional cobalt sulfate networks with organic templates or pillars. A previous report by Behera and Rao details the synthesis and characterization of a family of pillared cobalt sulfate networks, with general formula Co[HN(CH2)nNH]SO4 (sic) where n = 3–6 [12]. In this report we describe the synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal and magnetic properties of the analogous compound, Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1).

ExperimentalSolvothermal Crystal Growth of <bold>1</bold>

Crystals of 1 were obtained by solvothermal synthesis. A mixture of cobalt(II) sulfate heptahydrate (Co(SO4) · 7H2O, Fluka 97.5%) and ethylenediamine (C2H8N2, Fluka 99%) in ethylene glycol (BDH 98%) with Co(SO4) · 7H2O/ethylenediamine/ethylene glycol mole ratio of 1:1.5:117 was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 cm3) with ca. 50% filling capacity. The reaction was subjected to autogenous pressure while heated at 453 K for 72 h, and subsequently cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 K h−1. The product was then filtered and washed with ethanol. This synthesis afforded salmon-colored hexagonal bars and rose-colored plates. Preliminary single crystal X-ray diffraction studies showed that the hexagonal bars contained discrete tris(ethylenediamine)cobalt(II) units with the sulfate ion for charge balancing; the full data set was not collected. The subject of this work is solely on the crystal structure and properties of the rose plates, which were revealed later to be species 1.

Structure and Properties Characterization of <bold>1</bold>

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1 were collected at the microcrystal diffraction facility on station 16.2SMX of the Synchrotron Radiation Source, CCLRC Daresbury Laboratory, UK. A block of dimensions 80 μm × 35 μm × 35 μm was covered in perfluoropolyether oil and mounted at the end of a two stage glass fiber and cooled to 150 K in a nitrogen gas cryostream. Data were collected using a Bruker D8 diffractometer fitted with an APEXII CCD area detector. Data collection nominally comprised a sphere of reciprocal space by three series of ω-scans with different crystal φ orientation angles. Each frame employed a 0.36º rotation in ω and a 1 s exposure time. Reflection intensities were integrated using standard procedures [13] allowing for the plane polarized nature of the primary synchrotron beam. Semi-empirical corrections were applied to model absorption and incident beam decay [14]. Unit cell parameters were refined using all observed reflections. The structure was solved by routine automatic direct methods, and completed by least squares refinement based on all unique measured F2 values and difference Fourier methods [15–17]. Hydrogen atoms became visible in the Fourier difference plots in the latter stages of the refinement, and were placed using geometric considerations.

The rose colored crystals of 1 were separated from the bulk solid under an optical microscope for further characterization. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the ground crystals of 1 was obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer, operating with a Ni filtered CuKα radiation (λ = 1.540558 Å, 48 kV and 30 mA). The infrared spectrum was collected on a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR (4,000–400 cm−1, resolution 0.5 cm−1) using a KBr (BDH 98.5%) pellet prepared also from ground crystals. The quantities of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and sulfur were analyzed by a Perkin Elmer Series II 2400 CHN/S analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with an Elmer TGA7 thermal analysis system in the temperature range 323–873 K at a heating rate 0.33 K s−1 under a nitrogen flow. The magnetic behavior of the ground crystals of 1 was examined at 293 K in a magnetic field range ±10 kOe, using a VSM 7403 magnetometer.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure of <bold>1</bold>

1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system. Systematic absences suggested a choice of space groups, Pbc21 (a non-standard setting of No. 29) or Pbcm (No. 57). The structure could be solved in both, but it was apparent that the true space group is Pbcm when an analysis of missed symmetry in Pbc21 is carried out. The crystal structure details are given in Table 1. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Co-atom, one S-atom, three O-atoms and half an ethylenediamine moiety. The atomic coordinates and equivalent isotropic displacement parameters are summarized in Table 2, with selected bond distances and angles in Table 3. The refined figures are in good agreement with those reported for the analogous networks [12]. Bond valence sum (BVS) for the CoII center was calculated based on these data and a single point energy model with b = 0.37, Ro(Co–O) = 1.6920 and Ro(Co–N) = 1.6500 [18, 19], confirming the divalence of the CoII (BVS = 1.839).

It is apparent that the network of 1 is analogous to those obtained from longer chain diamines [12], suggesting a template function of the organic molecules. The coordination environments of the fundamental building units are shown as the ORTEP plot in Fig. 1. Each CoII center adopts a distorted octahedral environment of CoO4N2, where the metal is coordinated to four O-atoms from three SO4 units and two N-atoms from two cis ethylenediamine molecules. There are two types of the coordinated SO4, including two trans monodentate and one bidentate moieties, which results in two corner-sharing and one edge-sharing for each CoII with three neighboring SO4 tetrahedra. Each SO4 tetrahedral unit, on the other hand, links three neighboring CoO4N2 octahedra thereby leading to the formation of cobalt sulfate sheets along the ab plane (Fig. 2a). Within the sheet, there are present distorted hexagonal apertures of size 4.793(3) × 5.761(2) Å2, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra.

The adjacent sheets are linked via the ethyelenediamines through the CoII centers, giving a three-dimensional network of composition Co(μ-H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4. The equimolar ratio of CoII:SO4 should be noted. The ethylenediamines can be regarded as pillars between the sheets giving a regular spacing of 7.55 Å (the bridged CoII–CoII distance). This generates windows within the structure of size 2.70 × 3.80 Å2 (Fig. 2b); and, an overall extra-framework volume of 22.7% was calculated by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å from the framework [20]. These figures are comparable with those reported with the longer diamines [12]. The adjacent sheets are related by the centre of inversion and the overall packing pattern of ABAB along the c axis. Figure 3 shows the PXRD pattern of the ground crystals of 1 in comparison with the pattern simulated from the single crystal data. The presence of the preferred orientation in the PXRD pattern is consistent with the layered structure, and a d spacing of 6.87 Å can be calculated from the most intense 002 diffraction peak.

The analysis of hydrogen bonds as summarized in Table 4 and depicted in Fig. 4 reveals the presence of both moderate and weak hydrogen bonds, which are established between the ethylenediamines and the O-atoms of the SO4. This is believed to be an important factor in directing the spatial orientation of the organic pillars in relation to the networks.

We note that our composition differs from that in the analogous structures reported previously for longer diamines [12]. In particular, the ethylenediamine is fully protonated which is consistent with the divalence of CoII. This is consistent with the CHN/S analysis: Element, % calc. (% found): C, 26(29); H, 8.7(3.2); N, 30(32.5); S, 35(35.2); FT-IR (frequency (assignment)): 3327vs, 3321vs (νas(N–H; NH2)); 2889vs, 2955vs (νas(C–H; CH2)); 1591vs (δas(N–H)); 1475w, 1383m (δs(C–H; CH2)); 1330s (δs(N–H)); 1119vs (ν(C–N)); 1084vs (νs(S–O)); 1028vs (νas(S–O)); 785m (ρ(CH2)); 604vs (ω(N–H)); 505m (ν(Co–N)); 465m (ν(Co–O)).

As is often the case for data collected using synchrotron radiation, when all the other atoms are located and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, the hydrogen atoms attached to the ethylenediamine are located in the difference Fourier maps. The previous report of Co[HN(CH2)nNH]SO4 describes analogous structures but has a composition consistent with CoIV [12]. We are confident the present compound contains CoII and suggest the omission of protons in the previous report is an oversight. This can also be confirmed by the comparable bond lengths of 1 and other known CoII phases; 2.104(2)–2.229(2) Å and 2.111(2) Å for 1 compared with 2.076–2.234 Å and 2.097–2.151 Å for CoII–O and CoII–N, respectively [5–9, 12].

Thermal and Magnetic Properties of <bold>1</bold>

On heating the ground crystals of 1 under a nitrogen gas flow in the temperature range 323–873 K, three weight losses are observed (Fig. 5). The first is a gradual weight loss of ca. 2.8%, which occurs to ca. 373 K and corresponds presumably to the liberation of the surface water. The second weight loss of ca. 30% occurs between 623 K and 748 K and is consistent (calc. 28%) with the decomposition of the organic pillars. This suggests the possibility that the network may be thermally stable to temperatures well above 573 K. The weight loss continues to occur above 573 K, and may be due to the loss of SO3 and the collapse of the network. These assumptions are made by comparing the observed and calculated weight losses and the common thermal behaviors of the other organodiamine-metal sulfate networks [4, 5, 21–23].

Figure 6 shows the field dependent magnetization, M–H, curve of the ground crystals of 1. The data were collected at 293 K in the applied field range ±10 kOe. The results indicate a characteristic linear correlation with paramagnetic behavior, which corresponds to an effective magnetic moment of 4.6 μB per CoII atom. This value is comparable to the reported value, 4.8 μB, of analogous structures with longer diamines [12].

Conclusions

In summary, a three-dimensional network built of cobalt sulfate sheets and ethylenediamine pillars has been synthesized and characterized. The layered structure of the cobalt sulfate is unique in their regular alternating arrangement of the CoO4N2 octahedra and the SO4 tetrahedral units. The presence of ethylenediamine pillars, which link the adjacent sheets in an ABAB stacking fashion, results in intersecting channels in an infinite coordination network. The crystal structure has been fully characterized and reveals both coordination and hydrogen bonds to be important in introducing the order to the structure. The compound is thermally stable and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature with an effective magnetic moment per CoII atom of 4.6 μB, which is comparable to analogous structures with longer diamines.

Supplementary Material

Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for structure 1 has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (deposition numbers: CCDC 672268). Copies of this information may be obtained free of charge from The Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44 1223 336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

This can also be confirmed by the comparable bond lengths of 1 and other known CoII phases; 2.104(2)-2.229(2) Å and 2.111(2) Å for 1 compared with 2.076-2.234 Å and 2.097-2.151 Å for CoII-O and CoII-N, respectively [5-9, 12].Thermal and Magnetic Properties of 1On heating the ground crystals of 1 under a nitrogen gas flow in the temperature range 323-873 K, three weight losses are observed (Fig. 5). The first is a gradual weight loss of ca. 2.8%, which occurs to ca. 373 K and corresponds presumably to the liberation of the surface water. The second weight loss of ca. 30% occurs between 623 K and 748 K and is consistent (calc. 28%) with the decomposition of the organic pillars. This suggests the possibility that the network may be thermally stable to temperatures well above 573 K. The weight loss continues to occur above 573 K, and may be due to the loss of SO3 and the collapse of the network. These assumptions are made by comparing the observed and calculated weight losses and the common thermal behaviors of the other organodiamine-metal sulfate networks [4, 5, 21-23].Figure 6 shows the field dependent magnetization, M-H, curve of the ground crystals of 1. The data were collected at 293 K in the applied field range ±10 kOe. The results indicate a characteristic linear correlation with paramagnetic behavior, which corresponds to an effective magnetic moment of 4.6 μB per CoII atom. This value is comparable to the reported value, 4.8 μB, of analogous structures with longer diamines [12].ConclusionsIn summary, a three-dimensional network built of cobalt sulfate sheets and ethylenediamine pillars has been synthesized and characterized. The layered structure of the cobalt sulfate is unique in their regular alternating arrangement of the CoO4N2 octahedra and the SO4 tetrahedral units. The presence of ethylenediamine pillars, which link the adjacent sheets in an ABAB stacking fashion, results in intersecting channels in an infinite coordination network. The crystal structure has been fully characterized and reveals both coordination and hydrogen bonds to be important in introducing the order to the structure. The compound is thermally stable and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature with an effective magnetic moment per CoII atom of 4.6 μB, which is comparable to analogous structures with longer diamines.Supplementary MaterialCrystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for structure 1 has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (deposition numbers: CCDC 672268). elements.content: A pillared-layered coordination polymer of formula Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition, and fully characterized. The three-dimensional structure of 1 is built up from cobalt sulfate sheets, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra, with ethylenediamine pillars connecting the adjacent sheets. The coordinate covalent and hydrogen bonds have been revealed to exhibit an important role in the organization of the structure. The compound is found to be thermally stable up to, and above, 573 K and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A pillared-layered coordination polymer of formula Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition, and fully characterized. The three-dimensional structure of 1 is built up from cobalt sulfate sheets, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra, with ethylenediamine pillars connecting the adjacent sheets. The coordinate covalent and hydrogen bonds have been revealed to exhibit an important role in the organization of the structure. The compound is found to be thermally stable up to, and above, 573 K and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature.

elements.content: The best known of the three-dimensional open framework solids are the zeolites, which are composed solely of SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedral building units. These materials have found applications in a variety of fields such as catalysis, selective sorption, and ion exchange [1, 2]. Interest in these materials has been focused on the synthesis of similar extended networks with other tetrahedral units such as phosphate [3]. Another class of three-dimensional framework solids contemporarily capturing wide interest is of the pillared-layered structures [3]. In both classes of framework solids, the introduction of a transition metal into the framework has also been a key goal in recent years. Metal sulfate networks, in particular with cobalt sulfate, have been scarcely reported, although the sulfate group provides good thermal stability and the cobalt offers promising redox and magnetic properties [4, 5]. Moreover, the function of the sulfate in the reported structures is mostly limited to either a charge balancing guest or a terminal pendant unit [4–9]. There are, however, a few examples in which the sulfate acts as a bridge to establish the desired networks [10, 11]. In addition, most of these structures are of low (one or two) dimension.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The best known of the three-dimensional open framework solids are the zeolites, which are composed solely of SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedral building units. These materials have found applications in a variety of fields such as catalysis, selective sorption, and ion exchange [1, 2]. Interest in these materials has been focused on the synthesis of similar extended networks with other tetrahedral units such as phosphate [3]. Another class of three-dimensional framework solids contemporarily capturing wide interest is of the pillared-layered structures [3]. In both classes of framework solids, the introduction of a transition metal into the framework has also been a key goal in recent years. Metal sulfate networks, in particular with cobalt sulfate, have been scarcely reported, although the sulfate group provides good thermal stability and the cobalt offers promising redox and magnetic properties [4, 5]. Moreover, the function of the sulfate in the reported structures is mostly limited to either a charge balancing guest or a terminal pendant unit [4-9]. There are, however, a few examples in which the sulfate acts as a bridge to establish the desired networks [10, 11]. In addition, most of these structures are of low (one or two) dimension.

elements.content: Our work has focused on the search for new three-dimensional cobalt sulfate networks with organic templates or pillars. A previous report by Behera and Rao details the synthesis and characterization of a family of pillared cobalt sulfate networks, with general formula Co[HN(CH2)nNH]SO4 (sic) where n = 3–6 [12]. In this report we describe the synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal and magnetic properties of the analogous compound, Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1).
elements.clean_text: Our work has focused on the search for new three-dimensional cobalt sulfate networks with organic templates or pillars. A previous report by Behera and Rao details the synthesis and characterization of a family of pillared cobalt sulfate networks, with general formula Co[HN(CH2)nNH]SO4 (sic) where n = 3-6 [12]. In this report we describe the synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal and magnetic properties of the analogous compound, Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1).

elements.content: Crystals of 1 were obtained by solvothermal synthesis. A mixture of cobalt(II) sulfate heptahydrate (Co(SO4) · 7H2O, Fluka 97.5%) and ethylenediamine (C2H8N2, Fluka 99%) in ethylene glycol (BDH 98%) with Co(SO4) · 7H2O/ethylenediamine/ethylene glycol mole ratio of 1:1.5:117 was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 cm3) with ca. 50% filling capacity. The reaction was subjected to autogenous pressure while heated at 453 K for 72 h, and subsequently cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 K h−1. The product was then filtered and washed with ethanol. This synthesis afforded salmon-colored hexagonal bars and rose-colored plates. Preliminary single crystal X-ray diffraction studies showed that the hexagonal bars contained discrete tris(ethylenediamine)cobalt(II) units with the sulfate ion for charge balancing; the full data set was not collected. The subject of this work is solely on the crystal structure and properties of the rose plates, which were revealed later to be species 1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Solvothermal Crystal Growth of 1

Crystals of 1 were obtained by solvothermal synthesis. A mixture of cobalt(II) sulfate heptahydrate (Co(SO4) ⋅ 7H2O, Fluka 97.5%) and ethylenediamine (C2H8N2, Fluka 99%) in ethylene glycol (BDH 98%) with Co(SO4) ⋅ 7H2O/ethylenediamine/ethylene glycol mole ratio of 1:1.5:117 was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 cm3) with ca. 50% filling capacity. The reaction was subjected to autogenous pressure while heated at 453 K for 72 h, and subsequently cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 K h-1. The product was then filtered and washed with ethanol. This synthesis afforded salmon-colored hexagonal bars and rose-colored plates. Preliminary single crystal X-ray diffraction studies showed that the hexagonal bars contained discrete tris(ethylenediamine)cobalt(II) units with the sulfate ion for charge balancing; the full data set was not collected. The subject of this work is solely on the crystal structure and properties of the rose plates, which were revealed later to be species 1.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1 were collected at the microcrystal diffraction facility on station 16.2SMX of the Synchrotron Radiation Source, CCLRC Daresbury Laboratory, UK. A block of dimensions 80 μm × 35 μm × 35 μm was covered in perfluoropolyether oil and mounted at the end of a two stage glass fiber and cooled to 150 K in a nitrogen gas cryostream. Data were collected using a Bruker D8 diffractometer fitted with an APEXII CCD area detector. Data collection nominally comprised a sphere of reciprocal space by three series of ω-scans with different crystal φ orientation angles. Each frame employed a 0.36º rotation in ω and a 1 s exposure time. Reflection intensities were integrated using standard procedures [13] allowing for the plane polarized nature of the primary synchrotron beam. Semi-empirical corrections were applied to model absorption and incident beam decay [14]. Unit cell parameters were refined using all observed reflections. The structure was solved by routine automatic direct methods, and completed by least squares refinement based on all unique measured F2 values and difference Fourier methods [15–17]. Hydrogen atoms became visible in the Fourier difference plots in the latter stages of the refinement, and were placed using geometric considerations.
elements.clean_text:
Structure and Properties Characterization of 1

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1 were collected at the microcrystal diffraction facility on station 16.2SMX of the Synchrotron Radiation Source, CCLRC Daresbury Laboratory, UK. A block of dimensions 80 μm × 35 μm × 35 μm was covered in perfluoropolyether oil and mounted at the end of a two stage glass fiber and cooled to 150 K in a nitrogen gas cryostream. Data were collected using a Bruker D8 diffractometer fitted with an APEXII CCD area detector. Data collection nominally comprised a sphere of reciprocal space by three series of ω-scans with different crystal φ orientation angles. Each frame employed a 0.36º rotation in ω and a 1 s exposure time. Reflection intensities were integrated using standard procedures [13] allowing for the plane polarized nature of the primary synchrotron beam. Semi-empirical corrections were applied to model absorption and incident beam decay [14]. Unit cell parameters were refined using all observed reflections. The structure was solved by routine automatic direct methods, and completed by least squares refinement based on all unique measured F2 values and difference Fourier methods [15-17]. Hydrogen atoms became visible in the Fourier difference plots in the latter stages of the refinement, and were placed using geometric considerations.

elements.content: The rose colored crystals of 1 were separated from the bulk solid under an optical microscope for further characterization. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the ground crystals of 1 was obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer, operating with a Ni filtered CuKα radiation (λ = 1.540558 Å, 48 kV and 30 mA). The infrared spectrum was collected on a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR (4,000–400 cm−1, resolution 0.5 cm−1) using a KBr (BDH 98.5%) pellet prepared also from ground crystals. The quantities of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and sulfur were analyzed by a Perkin Elmer Series II 2400 CHN/S analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with an Elmer TGA7 thermal analysis system in the temperature range 323–873 K at a heating rate 0.33 K s−1 under a nitrogen flow. The magnetic behavior of the ground crystals of 1 was examined at 293 K in a magnetic field range ±10 kOe, using a VSM 7403 magnetometer.

The magnetic behavior of the ground crystals of 1 was examined at 293 K in a magnetic field range ±10 kOe, using a VSM 7403 magnetometer.

elements.content: 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system. Systematic absences suggested a choice of space groups, Pbc21 (a non-standard setting of No. 29) or Pbcm (No. 57). The structure could be solved in both, but it was apparent that the true space group is Pbcm when an analysis of missed symmetry in Pbc21 is carried out. The crystal structure details are given in Table 1. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Co-atom, one S-atom, three O-atoms and half an ethylenediamine moiety. The atomic coordinates and equivalent isotropic displacement parameters are summarized in Table 2, with selected bond distances and angles in Table 3. The refined figures are in good agreement with those reported for the analogous networks [12]. Bond valence sum (BVS) for the CoII center was calculated based on these data and a single point energy model with b = 0.37, Ro(Co–O) = 1.6920 and Ro(Co–N) = 1.6500 [18, 19], confirming the divalence of the CoII (BVS = 1.839).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1

1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system. Systematic absences suggested a choice of space groups, Pbc21 (a non-standard setting of No. 29) or Pbcm (No. 57). The structure could be solved in both, but it was apparent that the true space group is Pbcm when an analysis of missed symmetry in Pbc21 is carried out. The crystal structure details are given in Table 1. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Co-atom, one S-atom, three O-atoms and half an ethylenediamine moiety. The atomic coordinates and equivalent isotropic displacement parameters are summarized in Table 2, with selected bond distances and angles in Table 3. The refined figures are in good agreement with those reported for the analogous networks [12]. Bond valence sum (BVS) for the CoII center was calculated based on these data and a single point energy model with b = 0.37, Ro(Co-O) = 1.6920 and Ro(Co-N) = 1.6500 [18, 19], confirming the divalence of the CoII (BVS = 1.839).

It is apparent that the network of 1 is analogous to those obtained from longer chain diamines [12], suggesting a template function of the organic molecules. The coordination environments of the fundamental building units are shown as the ORTEP plot in Fig. 1. Each CoII center adopts a distorted octahedral environment of CoO4N2, where the metal is coordinated to four O-atoms from three SO4 units and two N-atoms from two cis ethylenediamine molecules. There are two types of the coordinated SO4, including two trans monodentate and one bidentate moieties, which results in two corner-sharing and one edge-sharing for each CoII with three neighboring SO4 tetrahedra. Each SO4 tetrahedral unit, on the other hand, links three neighboring CoO4N2 octahedra thereby leading to the formation of cobalt sulfate sheets along the ab plane (Fig. 2a). Within the sheet, there are present distorted hexagonal apertures of size 4.793(3) × 5.761(2) Å2, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra.

elements.content: The adjacent sheets are linked via the ethyelenediamines through the CoII centers, giving a three-dimensional network of composition Co(μ-H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4. The equimolar ratio of CoII:SO4 should be noted. The ethylenediamines can be regarded as pillars between the sheets giving a regular spacing of 7.55 Å (the bridged CoII–CoII distance). This generates windows within the structure of size 2.70 × 3.80 Å2 (Fig. 2b); and, an overall extra-framework volume of 22.7% was calculated by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å from the framework [20]. These figures are comparable with those reported with the longer diamines [12]. The adjacent sheets are related by the centre of inversion and the overall packing pattern of ABAB along the c axis. Figure 3 shows the PXRD pattern of the ground crystals of 1 in comparison with the pattern simulated from the single crystal data. The presence of the preferred orientation in the PXRD pattern is consistent with the layered structure, and a d spacing of 6.87 Å can be calculated from the most intense 002 diffraction peak.

elements.content: As is often the case for data collected using synchrotron radiation, when all the other atoms are located and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, the hydrogen atoms attached to the ethylenediamine are located in the difference Fourier maps. The previous report of Co[HN(CH2)nNH]SO4 describes analogous structures but has a composition consistent with CoIV [12]. We are confident the present compound contains CoII and suggest the omission of protons in the previous report is an oversight. This can also be confirmed by the comparable bond lengths of 1 and other known CoII phases; 2.104(2)–2.229(2) Å and 2.111(2) Å for 1 compared with 2.076–2.234 Å and 2.097–2.151 Å for CoII–O and CoII–N, respectively [5–9, 12].

elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a three-dimensional network built of cobalt sulfate sheets and ethylenediamine pillars has been synthesized and characterized. The layered structure of the cobalt sulfate is unique in their regular alternating arrangement of the CoO4N2 octahedra and the SO4 tetrahedral units. The presence of ethylenediamine pillars, which link the adjacent sheets in an ABAB stacking fashion, results in intersecting channels in an infinite coordination network. The crystal structure has been fully characterized and reveals both coordination and hydrogen bonds to be important in introducing the order to the structure. The compound is thermally stable and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature with an effective magnetic moment per CoII atom of 4.6 μB, which is comparable to analogous structures with longer diamines.

cln_elements.content: Crystals of 1 were obtained by solvothermal synthesis. A mixture of cobalt(II) sulfate heptahydrate (Co(SO4) · 7H2O, Fluka 97.5%) and ethylenediamine (C2H8N2, Fluka 99%) in ethylene glycol (BDH 98%) with Co(SO4) · 7H2O/ethylenediamine/ethylene glycol mole ratio of 1:1.5:117 was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 cm3) with ca. 50% filling capacity. The reaction was subjected to autogenous pressure while heated at 453 K for 72 h, and subsequently cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 K h−1. The product was then filtered and washed with ethanol. This synthesis afforded salmon-colored hexagonal bars and rose-colored plates. Preliminary single crystal X-ray diffraction studies showed that the hexagonal bars contained discrete tris(ethylenediamine)cobalt(II) units with the sulfate ion for charge balancing; the full data set was not collected. The subject of this work is solely on the crystal structure and properties of the rose plates, which were revealed later to be species 1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Solvothermal Crystal Growth of 1

Crystals of 1 were obtained by solvothermal synthesis. A mixture of cobalt(II) sulfate heptahydrate (Co(SO4) ⋅ 7H2O, Fluka 97.5%) and ethylenediamine (C2H8N2, Fluka 99%) in ethylene glycol (BDH 98%) with Co(SO4) ⋅ 7H2O/ethylenediamine/ethylene glycol mole ratio of 1:1.5:117 was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 cm3) with ca. 50% filling capacity. The reaction was subjected to autogenous pressure while heated at 453 K for 72 h, and subsequently cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 K h-1. The product was then filtered and washed with ethanol. This synthesis afforded salmon-colored hexagonal bars and rose-colored plates. Preliminary single crystal X-ray diffraction studies showed that the hexagonal bars contained discrete tris(ethylenediamine)cobalt(II) units with the sulfate ion for charge balancing; the full data set was not collected. The subject of this work is solely on the crystal structure and properties of the rose plates, which were revealed later to be species 1.

cln_elements.content:
A pillared-layered coordination polymer of formula Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition, and fully characterized. The three-dimensional structure of 1 is built up from cobalt sulfate sheets, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra, with ethylenediamine pillars connecting the adjacent sheets. The coordinate covalent and hydrogen bonds have been revealed to exhibit an important role in the organization of the structure. The compound is found to be thermally stable up to, and above, 573 K and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature.

Thermal and Magnetic Properties of <bold>1</bold>

On heating the ground crystals of 1 under a nitrogen gas flow in the temperature range 323–873 K, three weight losses are observed (Fig. 5). The first is a gradual weight loss of ca. 2.8%, which occurs to ca. 373 K and corresponds presumably to the liberation of the surface water. The second weight loss of ca. 30% occurs between 623 K and 748 K and is consistent (calc. 28%) with the decomposition of the organic pillars. This suggests the possibility that the network may be thermally stable to temperatures well above 573 K. The weight loss continues to occur above 573 K, and may be due to the loss of SO3 and the collapse of the network. These assumptions are made by comparing the observed and calculated weight losses and the common thermal behaviors of the other organodiamine-metal sulfate networks [4, 5, 21–23].

Figure 6 shows the field dependent magnetization, M–H, curve of the ground crystals of 1. The data were collected at 293 K in the applied field range ±10 kOe. The results indicate a characteristic linear correlation with paramagnetic behavior, which corresponds to an effective magnetic moment of 4.6 μB per CoII atom. This value is comparable to the reported value, 4.8 μB, of analogous structures with longer diamines [12].

Conclusions

In summary, a three-dimensional network built of cobalt sulfate sheets and ethylenediamine pillars has been synthesized and characterized. The layered structure of the cobalt sulfate is unique in their regular alternating arrangement of the CoO4N2 octahedra and the SO4 tetrahedral units. The presence of ethylenediamine pillars, which link the adjacent sheets in an ABAB stacking fashion, results in intersecting channels in an infinite coordination network. The crystal structure has been fully characterized and reveals both coordination and hydrogen bonds to be important in introducing the order to the structure. The compound is thermally stable and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature with an effective magnetic moment per CoII atom of 4.6 μB, which is comparable to analogous structures with longer diamines.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A pillared-layered coordination polymer of formula Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition, and fully characterized. The three-dimensional structure of 1 is built up from cobalt sulfate sheets, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra, with ethylenediamine pillars connecting the adjacent sheets. The coordinate covalent and hydrogen bonds have been revealed to exhibit an important role in the organization of the structure. The compound is found to be thermally stable up to, and above, 573 K and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature.

Thermal and Magnetic Properties of 1

On heating the ground crystals of 1 under a nitrogen gas flow in the temperature range 323-873 K, three weight losses are observed (Fig. 5). The first is a gradual weight loss of ca. 2.8%, which occurs to ca. 373 K and corresponds presumably to the liberation of the surface water. The second weight loss of ca. 30% occurs between 623 K and 748 K and is consistent (calc. 28%) with the decomposition of the organic pillars. This suggests the possibility that the network may be thermally stable to temperatures well above 573 K. The weight loss continues to occur above 573 K, and may be due to the loss of SO3 and the collapse of the network. These assumptions are made by comparing the observed and calculated weight losses and the common thermal behaviors of the other organodiamine-metal sulfate networks [4, 5, 21-23].

Figure 6 shows the field dependent magnetization, M-H, curve of the ground crystals of 1. The data were collected at 293 K in the applied field range ±10 kOe. The results indicate a characteristic linear correlation with paramagnetic behavior, which corresponds to an effective magnetic moment of 4.6 μB per CoII atom. This value is comparable to the reported value, 4.8 μB, of analogous structures with longer diamines [12].

Conclusions

In summary, a three-dimensional network built of cobalt sulfate sheets and ethylenediamine pillars has been synthesized and characterized. The layered structure of the cobalt sulfate is unique in their regular alternating arrangement of the CoO4N2 octahedra and the SO4 tetrahedral units. The presence of ethylenediamine pillars, which link the adjacent sheets in an ABAB stacking fashion, results in intersecting channels in an infinite coordination network. The crystal structure has been fully characterized and reveals both coordination and hydrogen bonds to be important in introducing the order to the structure. The compound is thermally stable and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature with an effective magnetic moment per CoII atom of 4.6 μB, which is comparable to analogous structures with longer diamines.
